I’m using gingelly oil, but any vegetable
or sunflower oil works. Add a few
pieces of cinnamon, some cardamom, cloves,
one teaspoon whole peppercorns.
If you have thick cinnamon, two pieces
will do. Then add five large thinly‑sliced
onions. Sauté for 2 minutes, then
add 10 large green chilies.
Traditional biryanis are hotter,
so you can adjust chili quantity
based on rice and meat amount.
Once onions turn translucent,
turn off heat and cool the mix.
When cool, grind it with a little water
to a fine paste. Set aside.
Next, for the green masala paste:
in the pan, add one teaspoon oil,
one bowl fresh mint leaves, one bowl chopped
coriander leaves, and a handful of fenugreek—
just enough for flavor. Sauté for 2–3 minutes
until wilted, cool completely,
then grind with a little water to a fine paste.
Now to cook the mutton:
in a pressure cooker, add
two teaspoons gingelly oil and
three tablespoons ghee—for richness. Or reduce ghee
and use more oil if preferred.
Add whole spices: one cinnamon, cloves,
cardamom pods, three star anise,
bay leaf, three mace pieces,
one teaspoon black salt? (stone flour),
one teaspoon shahi jeera, one teaspoon fennel—
keep flame low so spices don’t burn.
